instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
threads.message:
I had this board on the shelf for a while since I couldn't figure out the issue. It has already been UC'd and all the main power rails are present, the fan spins, cpu gets warm, usb mouse lights up but there was nothing showing on the screen, thunderbolt wasn't working and no chime. Thunderbolt comes from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> so I assume this may be a problem.

There was small liquid damage by the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> chip and I saw that <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> looked burned on Pin 1.
The VDD Pin, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBTLC</SIGNAL> measured 3.3v but I still replaced the chip.
When I removed <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> the pad for Pin1 was gone so I put a new chip on and ran a wire from Pin 1 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> to <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>.

After I finished replacing everything and plugged the charger in I saw I was only getting 2.6v on Pins 1 and 5 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> as well as on <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C0890</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C0891</CAPACITOR>. <RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR> which is no stuff had 3.3v on Pin 1 and 2.6v on Pin 2. Also, randomly I would see 3.3v on both pins 1/5. I'm not sure if the fan connector could be causing this because even though the fan is locked in it is loose and I can pull it out and if I push the fan cable a certain way the fan will spin at normal speed or high speed.

I removed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and plugged in the charger and <RESISTOR>R2040</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C1902</CAPACITOR> started measuring 3.3v but <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> still shows around 2.7v. I got 0v on Pin 5 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.
I measured in diode mode on <CAPACITOR>C0890</CAPACITOR> and got 0.54v.

What else could be pulling <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> down?

Coincidentally Louis has a video of this similar issue posted today.

All of these measurements were done with no external cables plugged into the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
threads.message:
PPVRTC is generated by <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, so without <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> it will never work.
You had a light on a USB mouse so the board was working!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
threads.message:
Okay but how come <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5RS3RS0_SYSCLKGEN</SIGNAL> show 2.7v with the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> chip on.

The board was working but nothing was showing on the screen nor was thunderbolt working and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> controls the thunderbolt chip.

Update: I put another <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> chip that I took from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board and now when I plug the charger in I dont get a fan spin anymore but I still get a light on the charger. I checked Pin 5/<CAPACITOR>C1902</CAPACITOR> and now I only get 2.05v and nothing on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. I'm not sure if I may have overheated the chip trying to take it off that tough board. 

When I removed the chip again and plugged the charger in I got 3.34v on <CAPACITOR>C1902</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
threads.message: If it starts then PPVRTC is good enough. I cannot diagnose anything if you use garbage chips and are not sure you soldered it correctly.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
threads.message:
You may be right the chip may have been bad because when I put back the chip that I got measurements from to start this thread the fan started spinning again and I got 2.6v on Pins 1 and 5 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>.

I will take another chip from these donor boards that I have. I don't have any more <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards but I do have plenty other air and pro boards.

Can I take from any board that uses this chip number "SLG3NB148CV" on the schematic?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> issue
